Development of wide spectrum photocatalysts have become research hotspot in efficient solar energy-chemical conversion. In this work, a novel CdS@Cu2-xS core-shell p-n heterojunction was designed by cation exchange method for photocatalytic H2 evolution. The formation of built-in electric field on CdS@Cu2-xS core-shell p-n heterojunction effectively accelerates the separation efficiency of photogenerated carriers. The highest photocatalytic hydrogen evolution rate is 8176.5 μmol g − 1h−1 over optimized CdS@1%Cu2-xS-2 p-n heterojunction, which is 3.85 times higher than hexagonal CdS. And the highest AQE of 2.60% is acquired at 475 nm. The enhanced photocatalytic activity of the CdS@Cu2-xS p-n heterojunction is mainly attributed to the effect of the built-in electric field generated by p-n heterojunction, which improves the separation efficiency of photogenerated carriers. More importantly, the formed CdS@Cu2-xS p-n heterojunction with built-in electric field steering photogenerated carrier separation was certified by in-situ XPS. This work provides effective strategy to construction of p-n heterojunction for wide spectrum photocatalysis. Graphic abstract A novel CdS@Cu2-xS core-shell p-n heterojunction was designed by cation exchange method for wide spectrum photocatalytic H2 evolution. The enhanced photocatalytic activity of the CdS@Cu2-xS p-n heterojunction is mainly attributed to the effect of the built-in electric field generated by p-n heterojunction, which improves the separation efficiency of photogenerated carriers. More importantly, the formed CdS@Cu2-xS p-n heterojunction with built-in electric field steering photogenerated charge separation was certified by the in-situ XPS Image, graphical abstract . Keywords CdS single crystal Cu2-xS, p-n heterojunction Built-in electric field Wide spectrum photocatalytic H2 evolution 1 Introduction Because of the environmental pollution caused by fossil fuels, the exploration of new clean energy to replace fossil fuels has attracted great attention. Photocatalyst decomposition of water under solar irradiation to produce renewable hydrogen has become an ideal solution with great potential to mitigate environmental pollution and energy shortage. Because of solar energy wide existence and no pollution, which is considered as an ideal renewable energy [1–3]. At present, the current research on photocatalysis has mainly concentrated in UV and visible light [4–7]. The development of efficient photocatalysts using solar energy, especially broad spectral response, remains a challenge. If the negative effect of photogenerated carrier recombination can be eliminated, the photocatalytic activity of catalyst will be significantly improved [3]. Recently, it is reported that some precious metals (such as Ag, Au, Pd, etc.) can be used as a co-catalyst to enhance the photothermal effect and photocatalytic activity of the catalyst [8–10]. However, the use of these precious metals is limited by their high cost. Therefore, developing cheap materials instead of noble metal elements is an effective strategy to solve the economic problems in photocatalytic applications. As expect, there are reported some non-precious metals (such as Ni (OH)2 and Cu etc.) have attracted wide attention as co-catalyst to improve the photocatalytic H2 evolution activity [11,12]. In addition, Cu2-xS has a suitable stoichiometric band gap (E g = 1.2∼2.1 eV), which can be used as a good co-catalyst to enhance the photocatalytic hydrogen evolution rate [13]. CdS is promising candidate material for photocatalytic H2 evolution that suitable band edge location and strong light absorption capacity has been widely studied [14]. More importantly, it has more negative flat band potential and narrow band gap, so it can take advantage of visible region of solar energy. Nevertheless, the photocatalytic hydrogen evolution activity of CdS decreases seriously due to photocarrier recombination and photocorrosion [15, 16]. Many measures have been taken to solve these problems. Such as load precious metals, element doping, constructing heterojunction and other measures to improve charge separation efficiency and reduce photocorrosion [14,25]. For example, the previous report construction of CdS core-Au plasmonic satellites nanostructure to enhance photocatalytic H2 evolution activity [17]. S doped Ta2O5 decorated CdS nanospheres were synthesized via interfacial diffusion, which achieves enhanced and stable photocatalytic H2 production activity [18]. MoS2 clusters as cocatalyst also enhance the photocatalytic activity of CdS nanorod [19]. Moreover, construction of heterojunction, such as Z-scheme heterojunction (CdS/ZnS, CdS@ZnIn2S4 etc.) [14, 15], CdS facet junctions [20], and Co3O4/CdS p-n heterojunction [21] also efficiently improved the photocatalytic activity of CdS. Recently, sulfur vacancies mediated interfacial charge transfer over CdS@CuS was fabricated for enhancing photocatalytic activity [22]. However, there is rarely report about designed surface plasmon resonance enhanced CdS@Cu2-xS p-n heterojunction for wide spectrum photocatalytic H2 evolution. Inspired by the above considerations, herein, a novel CdS@Cu2-xS core-shell p-n heterojunction was designed by cation exchange method for wide spectrum photocatalytic H2 evolution. Furthermore, the built-in electric field in CdS@Cu2-xS core-shell p-n heterojunction effectively accelerates the separation of photoinduced electron-hole pairs, accelerates the redox reaction, and thus improves the photocatalytic activity. Importantly, the charge transfer direction was analyzed by in-situ XPS, which proved that the construction of CdS@Cu2-xS p-n heterojunction was an important reason for improving the photocatalytic activity. In conclusion, the enhanced photocatalytic activity of the CdS@Cu2-xS core-shell p-n heterostructure catalyst is mainly due to the fact that Cu2-xS acts as a co-catalyst and forms p-n heterojunction with CdS and the built-in electric field promotes the separation of photogenerated carriers. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Preparation of photocatalysts 2.1.1 Synthesis of hexagonal cds single crystals The hexagonal CdS single crystals were prepared according to previously reported [20, 21]. Firstly, 10 mmol Cd (NO3)2·4H2O and 60 mmol Na2S·9H2O were dissolved in 25 mL deionized water and then the orange solution obtained was stirred for 30 min at room temperature. The obtained solution was transferred to a 50 mL teflon lined autoclave and reacted at 200 °C for 20 h. The precipitate was obtained by centrifugation, then washed several times with deionized water and ethanol to remove impurities and dried under vacuum at 60 °C for 5 h. Eventually, the hexagonal phase CdS single crystals were obtained. 2.1.2 Synthesis of CdS@Cu2-xS core-shell heterostructure CdS@Cu2-xS photocatalysts were fabricated by sequential cation exchange method. Firstly, 100 mg of CdS powders was added to 50 mL of deionized water and then well-mixed by sonication. Subsequently, 100 μL of 0.1 mol L − 1 CuCl2 aqueous solution was drop wised to the obtained CdS aqueous solution with continuous stirring for 2 h. Then, the resulting solution was centrifuged, washed with deionized water several times, and vacuum dried at 60 °C. Also, CdS@x%Cu2-xS-n (x = 0.5%, 2%, 3% and 4%) samples were added to different volumes (50 μL, 200 μL, 300 μL and 400 μL) of 0.1 mol L − 1 CuCl2 aqueous solution, using the same method. After that, the samples obtained by stirring for different times (0.5 h, 1 h, 2 h, 3 h and 4 h) were named as CdS@x%Cu2-xS-n (n = 0.5, 1, 2, 3 and 4). The detailed synthetic steps are present in Scheme 1 . 2.2 Characterizations The Cu kα radiation (Rigaku UItima III X-ray diffractometer) was used to analyze the crystal structure of the prepared photocatalysts. The morphology and microstructure of the CdS and CdS@Cu2-xS was characterized through field emission transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEM1200EX, JEOL, 100 kV) and field emission scanning electron microscopy (SEM, JSM-6701F, JEOL, 50 kV). The photoluminescence (PL) spectra were used to characterize light absorption characteristic as well as the lifetime of the prepared catalysts at excitation wavelength of 380 nm. The PL spectra were obtained using FLUORO-MAX-4 spectrophotometer and time-resolved fluorescence emission spectra were obtained using a Horiba Jobin Yvon Data Station HUB. The elemental composition, valence state and optical properties of the samples were characterized through X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, ESCALAB 250 xi). The in-situ XPS spectra were obtained from an electron spectrometer (XPS, ESCALAB 250 xi) under the light irradiation at λ=365 nm. The UV–Vis diffuse reflectance spectra (UV–Vis DRs) were measured by PerkinElmer Lambda-750 UV–Vis-NIR spectrometer with BaSO4 powder as a reference standard. The specific surface areas and pore size distributions of CdS and CdS@Cu2-xS samples were calculated by the nitrogen adsorption-desorption isothermal method with the data acquisition platform Micromeritics ASAP 2020. The Zeta potentials were recorded by Litesizer 500 in the water. The leaching amount of Cd2+ during the photoreaction was analysis by inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectrometer (ICP, OPTIMA7000DVICP-OES). 2.3 Photocatalytic H2 evolution The photocatalytic hydrogen evolution experiments were performed in quartz glass reaction flask. In the photocatalytic experiment, 6 mg photocatalyst was mixed with 30 mL of 10 v/v% lactic acid aqueous solution, and ultrasonic was used until the mixture was uniform, where the lactic acid solution was used as the sacrificial agent of holes. Before starting experiment, the reaction flask was placed in darkness and air in the reaction flask was removed by N2 degassing. A 5 W LED lamp (λ ≥ 420 nm) was used as light source for the photocatalytic H2 evolution experiments. The concentration of the produced hydrogen was recorded hourly by gas chromatography (Tianmei GC 7900, TCD, 13 X column) with nitrogen as the carrier gas. Additionally, the apparent quantum efficiency (AQE) is determined using 300 W Xe lamp as light source at different wavelengths. AQE was calculated using the following equation: (1) A Q E = 2 × the number of evolved hydrogen molecules the number of incident photons × 100 % 2.4 Electrochemical measurement Electrochemical tests were performed on VersaStat 4–400 conventional three-electrode battery. The 0.2 M Na2SO4 aqueous solution was used as electrolyte, platinum foil as counter electrode and saturated glycerol electrode (SCE) as reference electrode. The working electrode was prepared by dispersing 5 mg catalyst powder into 200 μL Nafion solution (C9H7BrN2S:C2H6O=1:9), and then ultrasonic formation of uniform mixture. The resulting suspension was then slowly dropped onto a 1 × 1 cm2 fluorine doped tin oxide (FTO) glass surface and dried under infrared light. The instantaneous photocurrent reaction was obtained by used a 300 W Xe lamp with a 420 nm cutoff filter at bias voltage of 0.2 V. The electrochemical impedance spectra (EIS) of the catalysts were measured at an applied potential of 0.2 V vs. SCE. Mott-Schottky plots were measured at voltages from −1.0 to 1.0 V vs. SCE under dark conditions and used to obtain flat band potentials of the CdS and CdS@Cu2-xS samples. The electrocatalytic activity of the samples was experimentally measured by linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) with measured scan rate of 5 mV s − 1. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Zeta potentials As shown in Fig. 1 , the zeta potentials values of CdS and CdS@Cu2-xS-2 were −20.64 mV and −25.76 mV, respectively. It is well known that the mutual repulsion and attraction of particles can be measured by the magnitude of the zeta potential. In normal circumstances, the greater absolute value of zeta potentials indicated the more stable the system [23]. Obviously, the zeta potentials of CdS@Cu2-xS-2 is more negative than pure CdS. The formation of CdS@Cu2-xS-2 surface electronegativity increases, indicating that the protons (H +) absorption capacity was improved, which was beneficial to improving the photocatalytic H2 evolution. 3.2 Phase structure and morphology analysis XRD patterns of pure CdS and CdS@Cu2-xS-2 samples are shown in Fig. 2 a. Obviously, the CdS has strong and sharp diffraction peaks in the XRD pattern, which indicates its good crystallinity. For the hexagonal CdS, there are seven strong characteristic diffraction peaks at 24.64 o, 26.32 o, 28.02 o, 36.44 o, 43.57 o, 47.64 o and 51.66 o, which correspond to (100), (002), (101), (102), (110), (103) and (112) planes of CdS (PDF#41–1049), respectively [22]. Notably, in comparison with hexagonal CdS, the peak intensity of CdS@Cu2-xS decreases at the peak intensity of 26.32 o, which may be due to the addition of Cu2+ ions, which replace part of Cd2+ ions. There was no characteristic peak of Cu2-xS in the XRD spectrum, which may be because there is less content of Cu2-xS. Otherwise, there is no observed impurity peaks in Fig. 2b, which indicated the purity of composites was high. And the diffraction peaks of CdS@Cu2-xS formed by sequential cation exchange at different times are very similar, which indicates that Cu2-xS does not change the structure of hexagonal CdS crystals. The overall morphology of the CdS and CdS@Cu2-xS samples was investigated by SEM. The CdS is a hexagonal phase structure with smooth surface and sharp edges, with a small number of laminated stacked hexagonal nanoplates on the surface in Fig. 3 a. Fig. 3b shows the hexagonal CdS surface has small particles and the surface becomes rough, which indicated the CdS@Cu2-xS-2 was successfully synthesized. At the same time, it can be found that after the formation of Cu2-xS through sequential cation exchange, the crystal structure of hexagonal CdS does not change significantly, which was also consistent with the XRD results. As depicted in Fig. 3c, the element mapping of CdS@Cu2-xS-2, in which the existence of Cd, S and Cu demonstrated the successful synthesis of CdS@Cu2-xS-2. The morphology and microstructure of CdS@Cu2-xS-2 were studied by transmission electron microscopy (TEM). Fig. 4 a and Fig. 4b shows the CdS@Cu2-xS-2 still has a hexagonal structure and a small amount of Cu2-xS with core-shell structure encapsulated on the pure CdS, which indicates the successful synthesis of the composite catalyst CdS@Cu2-xS. Fig. 4c and Fig. 4d show the high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) image of CdS@Cu2-xS-2. Obviously, the figure that there is an obvious interface between CdS and Cu2-xS, the lattice spacing indicates that there is an ultra-thin Cu2-xS layer on the surface of CdS. The lattice fringes of CdS@Cu2-xS-2 with 0.33 nm and 0.30 nm face spacing point to the (002) and (101) planes of CdS, while the lattice fringes with 0.29 nm and 0.23 nm face spacing point to the (282) and (139) planes of Cu2-xS, respectively. In summary, the above phenomena can prove that the preparation of CdS@Cu2-xS composite was successful. As shown in Fig. 5 and Table 1 , the specific surface area, pore size distribution and average particle size of pure CdS and CdS@Cu2-xS-2 were obtained through the N2 adsorption and desorption curves. CdS and CdS@Cu2-xS samples have type III isotherms in Fig. 5. According to the data in Table 1, the specific surface areas of CdS and CdS@Cu2-xS-2 are 8 m2 g − 1 and 38 m2 g − 1, respectively. Moreover, the average pore size of the CdS and CdS@Cu2-xS samples indicates that they are both mesoporous materials. Because of the larger specific surface area can provide active sites and effective charge transfer paths in photocatalytic reactions, which can improve photocatalytic H2 evolution performance [24–26]. The pore volumes of CdS and CdS@Cu2-xS-2 are 0.02 cm3 g − 1and the average pore sizes are 8 nm and 6 nm, respectively. Obviously, the pore volume and average pore size of the catalyst have little change, indicating the improvement of photocatalytic H2 evolution activity has little relationship with the pore volume and average pore size. 3.3 Photocatalytic hydrogen evolution activity and photostability Under visible light irradiation (λ ≥ 420 nm) and simulated solar, the photocatalytic H2 evolution activity of the CdS and CdS@Cu2-xS were tested by using 10 v/v% lactic acid aqueous solution as an empty holes sacrificial agent in Fig. 6 . CdS has strong light absorption capacity, but because of serious recombination of photogenerated carriers, the photocatalytic H2 evolution performance was not satisfactory [27, 28]. In Fig. 6a, the photocatalytic hydrogen evolution rate of CdS was 10.60 mmol g − 1 over 5 h, while CdS@Cu2-xS-2 shows high photocatalytic H2 evolution rate of 40.88 mmol g − 1. This result indicates that the Cu2-xS shell generated by sequential cation exchange make CdS@Cu2-xS has high charge separation efficiency. Fig. 6b shows the corresponding photocatalytic hydrogen evolution rates of CdS@Cu2-xS composite with different contents of Cu2-xS under visible light irradiation (λ ≥ 420 nm). The photocatalytic H2 evolution rate of CdS@Cu2-xS was improved after adding Cu2-xS. Obviously, the highest hydrogen evolution rate of CdS@1%Cu2-xS-2 is 8176.5 µmol h − 1 g − 1, which is 3.85 times higher than hexagonal CdS. The improvement of photocatalytic activity could be attributed to the p-n heterojunction and built-in electric field formed by CdS@Cu2-xS. Notably, the H2 evolution of CdS@Cu2-xS composite decreases with increasing Cu2-xS content. This may be because excessive Cu2-xS would cover the active sites the CdS, hindering the redox reaction, thereby reducing the overall efficiency. Fig. 6c shows the corresponding hydrogen evolution of CdS@1%Cu2-xS generated by sequential cation exchange at different times under visible light irradiation (λ ≥ 420 nm). Obviously, CdS@Cu2-xS-2 has the highest photocatalytic activity when the reaction time was 2 h. It is noteworthy, the photocatalytic hydrogen evolution activity of CdS@Cu2-xS decreases with the extension of reaction times. This phenomenon may be due to the formation of excessive Cu2-xS coating on CdS surface with the extension of reaction times, which hinders the reduction reaction of CdS surface. Fig. 6d shows the corresponding hydrogen evolution process of CdS@Cu2-xS-2 under visible light (λ ≥ 420 nm) and simulated solar irraditaion (AM 1.5 Xe lamp). Obviously, the composite catalyst CdS@Cu2-xS-2 has higher photocatalytic H2 evolution activity under simulated solar, which also shows its broad spectral response. The stability of photocatalysis is always considered as an extremely important aspect in practical applications. Therefore, four photocatalytic H2 evolution experiments were carried out to prove the stability of CdS@Cu2-xS-2. The CdS@Cu2-xS-2 composite still maintained high activity after four times of photocatalytic reaction, indicating its good stability in Fig. 7 a. The XRD analysis of fresh and used CdS@Cu2-xS-2 sample (Fig. 7b) further proved the good stability. Obviously, compared with fresh CdS@Cu2-xS-2, the characteristic peaks of the used CdS@Cu2-xS-2 did not change significantly, which indicates the stability is well maintained. In addition, the wavelength-dependent apparent quantum efficiency (AQE) of H2 production is depicted in Fig. 7c, the highest AQE of 2.6% is acquired at 475 nm for CdS@Cu2-xS-2, which in accord with the light absorption capacity. The leaching of Cd2+ during the photoreaction of CdS and CdS@Cu2-xS-2 was investigated by inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES), and the results are shown in Fig. 7d. Obviously, compared with the CdS sample, the leaching concentration of Cd2+ in CdS@Cu2-xS-2 was reduced. This is because the formation of p-n heterojunction and built-in electric field promotes the separation and transfer of photogenerated carriers and enhances the photocatalytic hydrogen evolution activity. In addition, the precipitation concentration of Cd2+ in CdS@Cu2-xS-2 decreased, indicating that the photocorrosion resistance of CdS@Cu2-xS-2 composite catalyst was improved. Additionally, as shown in Table 2 , it is the comparison between this work and other related work. It can be found that the hydrogen evolution activity of CdS@Cu2-xS-2 reported in this work is still higher than that reported works. This indicates that CdS@Cu2-xS-2 photocatalyst has great hydrogen evolution potential. 3.4 Optical properties and band structure UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (UV–vis DRS) was used to study the optical properties of CdS and CdS@Cu2-xS samples. As we all know, the light absorption capacity was one of the important factors affecting photocatalyst activity. Obviously, Fig. 8 a shows that pure CdS has an obvious absorption band edge at 557 nm, which promise the result of intrinsic band gap absorption [28, 43]. Furthermore, according to the Tauc equation: αhν=A(hν-Eg)1/2 , the corresponding bandgap energy to CdS and CdS@Cu2-xS-2 was calculated. For direct bandgap semiconductor, thereinto α is absorption coefficient, A is a constant, h is the Planck constant, ν is the frequency, and E g is the bandgap energy [43]. As shown in Fig. 8b, the bandgap values of the pure CdS and CdS@Cu2-xS-2 were calculated to be 2.32 eV and 2.37 eV, respectively. The Mott-Schottky curve of CdS was used to study the flat-band potential (E fb) the genes of the semiconductor according to the plot shown in Fig. 8c. The Mott-Schottky curve of CdS composites has a positive slope, which indicated that the CdS composites have typical n-type semiconductor properties and the E fb for CdS is −0.81 V vs. SCE [44]. It is well known that the conduction band potential (E CB) of n-type semiconductors was −0.1 or −0.2 V more negative than its plane potential [45]. Given that the bandgap value of CdS is 2.32 eV, according to the equation: E NHE=E CB+0.241 V, E VB=E CB+E g, so it can be obtained the E CB and E VB are −0.67 V and 1.65 V vs. NHE, respectively. As presented in Fig. 8c and Fig. 8d, it can be found that the band gap of CdS@Cu2-xS is more negative than pure CdS, which indicating reduction ability of the catalyst after cation exchange is enhanced, thus improving the hydrogen evolution rate. 3.5 Surface-chemical structure and charge transfer The surface chemistry of CdS and CdS@Cu2-xS was analyzed using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The coexistence of Cd, S and Cu elements in the measured spectra of CdS@Cu2-xS composites as shown in Fig. 9 a, which indicating the successful in situ growth of Cu2-xS on the CdS surface through sequential cation exchange reactions. There is no impurity peak in the measurement spectra of CdS and CdS@Cu2-xS sample, which indicates that the synthesized catalyst has high purity. Moreover, except for the peak position of Cu 2p, the peak position of CdS has no obvious displacement compared with CdS@Cu2-xS. Fig. 9b shows the XPS spectra of Cd 3d the peaks values are 405.11 eV and 411.87 eV corresponding to Cd 3d5/2 and Cd 3d3/2 in CdS@Cu2-xS, respectively. The peak position corresponding to Cd 3d in CdS@Cu2-xS sample moved to a higher binding energy position, which possible that the exchange of Cd and Cu reducing the coordination with S [24]. Fig. 9c shows that the binding energies of S 2p in CdS@Cu2-xS are at 161.41 eV and 162.63 eV, belonging to S 2p3/2 and S 2p1/2, respectively. Moreover, the peak positions of S 2p for pure CdS are located at 160.86 eV and 162.05 eV. The corresponding peak positions of CdS@Cu2-xS-2 are all shifted to the higher binding energy compared to pure CdS. Generally, the increase of binding energy means the decrease of electron density, so it can be inferred that electrons transfer from CdS to Cu2-xS, which leads to the increase of binding energy of CdS@Cu2-xS after recombination. Fig. 9d shows the XPS spectra belonging to Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p1/2 at 932.47 eV and 952.37 eV, which are consistent with the previously reported results [3]. Meanwhile, as shown in Fig. 9d, the characteristic peak located at 568.99 eV in the X-ray excited Auger electron spectra (XAES) of Cu LM2 can be attributed to the metal Cu+. These results verify the successful synthesis of CdS@Cu2-xS composite. Furthermore, the XPS spectra of CdS@Cu2-xS-2 measured under UV-irradiated conditions (Fig. 9b and Fig. 9d). Fig. 9b shows the binding energy of Cd 3d in the CdS@Cu2-xS sample after under UV-irradiation decreases compared with that before UV-irradiation, indicating that the electron density on the CdS increased after UV-irradiation, which accelerated the reduction reaction process and enhanced the photocatalytic hydrogen precipitation performance. Additionally, the binding energy of Cu 2p for CdS@Cu2-xS-2 increases after UV-irradiation, indicating that the electron density of Cu2-xS decreases in Fig. 9d. The above results can prove the formation of p-n heterojunction enables electrons transfer from Cu2-xS to CdS. The separation of photoelectron-hole pairs was accelerated by the built-in electric field formed through p-n heterojunction, thus improving photocatalytic activity. The effect of Cu2-xS on the carrier separation efficiency of CdS@Cu2-xS composite was studied by using photoluminescence (PL) spectroscopy. As shown in Fig. 10 a, CdS has strong and wide PL emission peak at 524 ∼ 572 nm, which conforms to the nature of CdS exciton emission [45]. Moreover, the pure CdS had five distinct emission peaks at 466 nm, 481 nm, 491 nm, 576 nm and 622 nm. The fluorescence emission peaks at 466 nm, 481 nm, 491 nm and 527 nm belong to the near-band-edge emission. The PL spectrum at 576 nm and 622 nm could attributed to the surface sulfur vacancy defects [46–48]. Obviously, the luminescence intensity of CdS@Cu2-xS is significantly lower than pure CdS. These results indicate the Cu2-xS was favorable for the spatial separation of CdS@Cu2-xS-2 photogenerated carriers. Moreover, the prepared CdS and CdS@Cu2-xS-2 samples were tested by time-resolved optical transfer (TRPL) to understand the dynamic photoinduced carrier transfer process. As shown in Fig. 10b and Table 3 , the attenuation curves were fitted by three-exponential decay model with the following equation: (2) I ( t ) = ∑ i = 1 , 2 , 3 B i exp ( − t / τ i ) I is the normalized emission intensity; t is the time after the pulsed laser excitation; τi is the respective decay lifetimes; Bi is the corresponding weight factors. (3) τ i = ∑ i = 1 , 2 , 3 B i τ i 2 / ∑ i = 1 , 2 , 3 B i τ i <τ> is the average lifetime; τi is the respective decay lifetimes; Bi is the corresponding weight factors. The average lifetimes of CdS and CdS@Cu2-xS-2 samples were 2.00 ns and 2.28 ns, respectively. Fig. 10b shown CdS@Cu2-xS-2 composite has a longer average lifetime than pure CdS, which indicating CdS@Cu2-xS-2 has good photoexcited carrier separation efficiency, which again strongly demonstrates the unique advantages of this sequential cation exchange. At the same time, the CdS@Cu2-xS-2 samples have relatively long average lifetimes and show long apparent carrier diffusion distances, which favor the transfer of photogenerated charge to catalyst contact interface. Therefore, the photocatalytic H2 precipitation activity of the catalyst was enhanced. The charge separation and transfer efficiency of synthetic catalysts were further investigated by using transient photocurrent response. As shown in Fig. 11 a, the photocurrent is significantly enhanced after continuous cation exchange of CdS@Cu2-xS compared to pure CdS. The result was consistent with the improved activity of photocatalytic H2 evolution, which indicating electron-hole pairs separation efficiency of CdS@Cu2-xS composite is higher. Furthermore, the electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was used to study the charge separation and transfer processes in the dark environment (Fig. 11b). The EIS plots of the CdS@Cu2-xS composite photocatalyst showed good electrical conductivity in the non-photoexcited state compared to pure CdS [46]. This result strongly proves that Cu2-xS generated by sequential cation exchange promoted the charge transfer rate. As presented in Fig. 11c, the electrochemical H2 evolution activities of CdS and CdS@Cu2-xS electrodes was tested through the linear sweep voltammetry (LSV). The overpotential of hexagonal CdS is about −0.57 V, while that of CdS@Cu2-xS is lower (−0.50 V), declaring that the CdS@Cu2-xS improves the electron transport efficiency of H2 evolution reaction [49, 50]. 3.6 Possible mechanism for photocatalytic H2 production Based on the above results, the mechanism of photocatalytic H2 evolution reaction of CdS@Cu2-xS core-shell p-n heterojunction was proposed in Fig. 12 . Under visible light irradiation (λ ≥ 420 nm), the electron-hole pairs generated in hexagonal CdS crystals were separated and transferred to the surface of the composite catalyst. Because the Fermi levels of n-type semiconductor is close to the conduction band (CB) and the Fermi level of p-type semiconductor was closed to the valence band (VB), both CdS and Cu2-xS remain relatively stable until contact [44]. After the contact, the diffusion does not stop until the Fermi level of the system reaches equilibrium. At the same time, the built-in electric field was generated CdS and Cu2-xS, which improves the separation efficiency of photogenerated carriers. The CdS@Cu2-xS core-shell also promoted photocatalytic H2 evolution. After the CdS@Cu2-xS core-shell was irradiated, which CdS and Cu2-xS can generate electron-hole pairs. In the presence of the built-in electric field, the electrons in the CB of Cu2-xS are transferred to the CB of CdS and the holes in the VB of CdS are transferred to the VB of Cu2-xS. In summary, the built-in electric field formed by p-n heterojunction and its core-shell structure promote the separation of photogenerated electron-hole pairs, so that the photogenerated electrons will concentrate on the CB of pure CdS to reduce H + to H2. At the same time, the holes were accumulated in VB of Cu2-xS and eliminated by sacrificial reagent oxidation. Thus, the high photocatalytic H2 evolution activity was obtained on CdS@Cu2-xS core-shell p-n heterojunction. 4 Conclusions In summary, a novel surface plasmon resonance enhanced CdS@Cu2-xS core-shell p-n heterojunction was designed by cation exchange method for photocatalytic H2 production. The photoelectron-hole pair separation is effectively accelerated through the built-in electric field on the formed CdS@Cu2-xS p-n heterojunction. Therefore, the highest photocatalytic H2 evolution rate on the CdS@Cu2-xS-2 p-n heterojunction is 8176.5 μmol g − 1 h − 1, which was about 3.85 times higher than that of pure hexagonal CdS. And the highest AQE of 2.60% is acquired at 475 nm. The superiority of the photocatalytic performance over the CdS@Cu2-xS-2 composites was attributed to the interfacial charge transfer kinetics and the heterojunction structure formed in the larger interfacial contact region. The TRPL results further demonstrated effective space charge separation. Additionally, the formed CdS@Cu2-xS p-n heterojunction with built-in electric field steering photogenerated charge separation was certified by the in-situ XPS. This work provides an effective strategy for the construction and design of p-n heterojunction for wide-spectrum solar hydrogen evolution. coredata.dc:description: Development of wide spectrum photocatalysts have become research hotspot in efficient solar energy-chemical conversion. In this work, a novel CdS@Cu2-xS core-shell p-n heterojunction was designed by cation exchange method for photocatalytic H2 evolution. The formation of built-in electric field on CdS@Cu2-xS core-shell p-n heterojunction effectively accelerates the separation efficiency of photogenerated carriers. The highest photocatalytic hydrogen evolution rate is 8176.5 μmol g − 1h−1 over optimized CdS@1%Cu2-xS-2 p-n heterojunction, which is 3.85 times higher than hexagonal CdS. And the highest AQE of 2.60% is acquired at 475 nm. The enhanced photocatalytic activity of the CdS@Cu2-xS p-n heterojunction is mainly attributed to the effect of the built-in electric field generated by p-n heterojunction, which improves the separation efficiency of photogenerated carriers. More importantly, the formed CdS@Cu2-xS p-n heterojunction with built-in electric field steering photogenerated carrier separation was certified by in-situ XPS. This work provides effective strategy to construction of p-n heterojunction for wide spectrum photocatalysis.
coredata.dc:title: Construction of CdS@Cu2-xS core−shell p-n heterojunction with enhanced charge separation for wide spectrum photocatalytic H2 evolution
